p: The second major lignan of sesame is sesamolin [ 50, 72]. The name sesamolin was coined in 1928 by W. Adriani [ 69] for a crystalline compound with a melting point of 94 Â°C, which was isolated from sesame oil for the first time in 1903 in Italy [ 68]. The structure of sesamolin was determined in 1955 at the University of Sheffield [ 70].
